11 /** Represents the kind of a tiro value. */
12 typedef enum tiro_kind {
13  TIRO_KIND_NULL = 0, ///< Value is null
14  TIRO_KIND_BOOLEAN, ///< Value is true or false
15  TIRO_KIND_INTEGER, ///< Value is an integer
16  TIRO_KIND_FLOAT, ///< Value is a floating point number
17  TIRO_KIND_STRING, ///< Value is a string
18  TIRO_KIND_FUNCTION, ///< Value is a function
19  TIRO_KIND_TUPLE, ///< Value is a tuple
20  TIRO_KIND_RECORD, ///< Value is a record
21  TIRO_KIND_ARRAY, ///< Value is an array
22  TIRO_KIND_RESULT, ///< Value is a result
23  TIRO_KIND_COROUTINE, ///< Value is a coroutine
24  TIRO_KIND_MODULE, ///< Value is a module
25  TIRO_KIND_TYPE, ///< Value is a type
26  TIRO_KIND_NATIVE, ///< Value is a native object
27  TIRO_KIND_INTERNAL = 1000, ///< Value is some other, internal type
28  TIRO_KIND_INVALID, ///< Invalid value (e.g. null handle)
29 } tiro_kind_t;
30 
31 /**
32  * Returns the name of the kind, formatted as a string.
33  * The string points into static storage and must not be freed.
34  */
35 TIRO_API const char* tiro_kind_str(tiro_kind_t kind);
36 
37 /**
38  * Represents a value in the tiro language.
39  *
40  * Values cannot be used directly through the API. Instead, all operations on values must
41  * be done through a `tiro_handle_t`. Handles are a wrapper type around a value which ensures that
42  * their inner value always remains valid, even if garbage collection is triggered.
43  *
44  * \warning
45  * Handles may only be used when obtained from a function of this API (such as `tiro_frame_slot()`).
46  * They must never be initialized manually!
47  *
48  * A value stored in a valid handle is always considered *live*, which means that the garbage collector
49  * will not destroy it. If the garbage collector decides to move a value (which would change its address),
50  * the handles refering to that address will be updated automatically in a process that is completely transparent to the user.
51  */
52 struct tiro_value;
53 
54 /** Returns the kind of the handle's current value. */
55 TIRO_API tiro_kind_t tiro_value_kind(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value);
56 
57 /** Outputs a string representing the given value. The string is assigned to `result`. */
58 TIRO_API void
59 tiro_value_to_string(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
60 
61 /** Copies the current `value` to `result`. */
62 TIRO_API void
63 tiro_value_copy(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
64

66  * Returns the type of the given `value` by assigning it to `result`.

69 TIRO_API void
70 tiro_value_type(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

75  */
76 TIRO_API void
77 tiro_kind_type(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_kind_t kind, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

85 /**
86  * Returns `value` converted to a boolean value. `false` and `null` are considered false, all other values will return `true`.

91 TIRO_API void
92 tiro_make_integer(tiro_vm_t vm, int64_t value, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

94 /**
95  * Returns `value` converted to an integer. This function supports conversion for floating point values
96  * (they are truncated to an integer). All other values return 0 (use `tiro_value_kind` to disambiguate between types).
97  */
98 TIRO_API int64_t tiro_integer_value(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value);

103 /**
104  * Returns the floating point of `value`. This function supports conversion for integer values, all
105  * other values will return 0 (use `tiro_value_kind` to disambiguate between types).
106  */
107 TIRO_API double tiro_float_value(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t value);

109 /**
110  * Constructs a new string with the given content. `value` must be zero terminated or NULL. Passing NULL
111  * for `value` creates an empty string. Returns `TIRO_ERROR_ALLOC` on allocation failure.
112  */
113 TIRO_API void
114 tiro_make_string(tiro_vm_t vm, const char* value, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
115 
116 /**
117  * Constructs a new string with the given content. `data` must consist of `length` readable bytes.
118  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_ALLOC` on allocation failure.
119  */
120 TIRO_API void tiro_make_string_from_data(
121  tiro_vm_t vm, const char* data, size_t length, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
122 
123 /**
124  * Retrieves the string's content as a (data, length)-pair without copying the data. The pointer to the string's
125  * storage will be placed in `*data`, and the length (in bytes) will be assigned to `*length`.
126  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the value is not actually a string.
127  *
128  * \warning
129  * The string content returned through `data` and `length` is a view into the string's current storage. Because objects
130  * may move on the heap (e.g. because of garbage collection), this data may be invalidated. The data may only be used
131  * immediately after calling this function, and must not be used after another possibly allocating tiro_* function has been called.
132  *
133  * \warning
134  * The string returned by this function is not zero terminated.
135  */
136 TIRO_API void tiro_string_value(
137  tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t string, const char** data, size_t* length, tiro_error_t* err);
138 
139 /**
140  * Retrieves the string's content and creates a new zero terminated c string, which is assigned to `*result`.
141  * `*result` is only assigned to if the construction of the string succeeded (in which case `TIRO_OK` will be returned).
142  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the value is not actually a string.
143  *
144  * If `TIRO_OK` was returned, then `*result` must be passed to `free` for cleanup.
145  */
146 TIRO_API void
147 tiro_string_cstr(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t string, char** result, tiro_error_t* err);
148

150 TIRO_API void tiro_make_tuple(tiro_vm_t vm, size_t size, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

152 /** Returns the tuple's size, or 0 if the given value is not a tuple (use `tiro_value_kind` to disambiguate between types). */

155 /**
156  * Retrieves the tuple element at the given `index` from `tuple` and assigns it to `result`, unless an error occcurs.
157  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the instance is not a tuple, or `TIRO_ERROR_OUT_OF_BOUNDS` if the index is out of bounds.
158  */
159 TIRO_API void tiro_tuple_get(
160  tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t tuple, size_t index, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

169 /**
170  * Constructs a new record with the given key names. `keys` must be an array consisting of strings (which mus be unique).
171  * The specified keys will be valid propery names on the new record. The value associated with each key will be initialized to null.
172  *
173  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if `keys` is not an array, or if its contents are not all strings.
174  * On success, the constructed record will be assigned to `result`.
175  */
176 TIRO_API void
177 tiro_make_record(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t keys, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);

179 /** Retrieves an array of valid keys for the given record. Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the instance is not a record. */
180 TIRO_API void
181 tiro_record_keys(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t record, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
182 
183 /**
184  * Retrieves the value associated with the given key on this record. On success, the value will be assigned to `result`.
185  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the instance is not a record, or if `key` is not a string.
186  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_KEY` if the key is invalid for this record.
187  */
188 TIRO_API void tiro_record_get(
189  tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t record, tiro_handle_t key, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
190 
191 /**
192  * Sets the record's value associated with the given `key` to `value`.

194  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_KEY` if the key is invalid for this record.
195  */
196 TIRO_API void tiro_record_set(
197  tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t record, tiro_handle_t key, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_error_t* err);

259 /**

262  * if the instance is no result at all.

267 /**
268  * Constructs a new coroutine that will execute the given function.
269  * Note that the coroutine will not be started before passing it to `tiro_coroutine_start`.
270  *
271  * `func` must be a value of kind `TIRO_KIND_FUNCTION`, otherwise `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` is returned.
272  *
273  * `arguments` may be a NULL handle, a handle referencing a null value (to pass no arguments) or a tuple of values
274  * that will be passed to the function as arguments.
275  *
276  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_ALLOC` on allocation failure.
277  */
278 TIRO_API void tiro_make_coroutine(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t func, tiro_handle_t arguments,
279  tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
280 
281 /** Returns true if the coroutine has been started, false otherwise. */
282 TIRO_API bool tiro_coroutine_started(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coroutine);
283 
284 /** Returns true if the coroutine has finished its execution, false otherwise. */
285 TIRO_API bool tiro_coroutine_completed(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coroutine);
286 
287 /**
288  * Returns the coroutine's result by assigning it to `result`. The coroutine must have completed execution, i.e.
289  * `tiro_coroutine_completed()` must return true (for example, when invoked from a coroutine's completion callback).
290  */
291 TIRO_API void tiro_coroutine_result(
292  tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coroutine, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
293 
294 /**
295  * Represents a coroutine completion callback. These are invoked when a coroutine finishes execution,
296  * either successfully or with an error.
297  *
298  * \param vm
299  * The virtual machine the coroutine was running on.
300  * \param coro
301  * The completed coroutine.
302  * \param userdata
303  * The original userdata pointer that was provided when the callback was registered.
304  */
305 typedef void (*tiro_coroutine_callback)(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coro, void* userdata);
306 
307 /**
308  * Represents a cleanup function associated with a coroutine callback. Cleanup functions are always executed immediately
309  * after the callback was invoked, or when the virtual machine is shutting down prior to the coroutine's completion.
310  * The cleanup function is always executed exactly once.
311  *
312  * \param userdata
313  * The original userdata pointer that was provided when the callback was registered.
314  *
315  * TODO: Does the cleanup function need access to the vm instance?
316  */
317 typedef void (*tiro_coroutine_cleanup)(void* userdata);
318 
319 /**
320  * Schedules the given callback to be invoked once the coroutine completes.
321  *
322  * `coroutine` must be a handle to a coroutine, otherwise `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` is returned.
323  *
324  * `callback` will be invoked when the coroutine completes its execution. A coroutine completes when the outermost function
325  * returns normally or if an uncaught exception is thrown from that function. The callback receives a handle to the completed coroutine,
326  * which can be inspected in order to retrieve the coroutine's result, and the original `userdata` argument.
327  * It will *not* be invoked if the virtual machine shuts down before the coroutine has completed.
328  * The callback must not be NULL, otherwise `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_ARG` will be returned.
329  *
330  * Note: all callback invocations happen from within one of the `tiro_vm_run*` functions.
331  *
332  * `cleanup` will be invoked to release state that may be owned by the callback. It will be called directly after the callback
333  * has been invoked, or as part of the virtual machine's shutdown procedure. The cleanup function receives the original `userdata` argument.
334  * When present, `cleanup` will be called exactly once. The `cleanup` function is optional.
335  *
336  * `userdata` will be passed to `callback` and `cleanup` when appropriate, and it will not be used in any other way.
337  */
338 TIRO_API void
339 tiro_coroutine_set_callback(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coroutine, tiro_coroutine_callback callback,
340  tiro_coroutine_cleanup cleanup, void* userdata, tiro_error_t* err);
341 
342 /**
343  * Starts the given coroutine by scheduling it for execution. The coroutine must not have been started before.
344  * Coroutines are not invoked from this function. They will be executed from within one of the `tiro_vm_run*` functions.
345  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the argument is not a coroutine, or `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_STATE` if the coroutine cannot be started.
346  */
347 TIRO_API void tiro_coroutine_start(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t coroutine, tiro_error_t* err);
348 
349 typedef struct tiro_module_member_t {
350  const char* name; // TODO ptr+length instead of c string? or use a tiro_handle_t with a string?
351  tiro_handle_t value;
352 } tiro_module_member_t;
353 
354 /**
355  * Creates a new module with the given `name` from the given `members` list.
356  *
357  * `name` must be a valid, null terminated string and non-empty string.
358  *
359  * `members` must be a valid pointer that points to
360  * `members_length` entries. When the module has been created successfully, it will be written to `result`.
361  *
362  * \note All members listed in this function call will be exported by the module.
363  *
364  * TODO: Do we need an API for non-exported members?
365  */
366 TIRO_API void tiro_make_module(tiro_vm_t vm, const char* name, tiro_module_member_t* members,
367  size_t members_length, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
368 
369 /**
370  * Attempts to retrieve the exported module member called `export_name` from the given module.
371  * On success, the member will be written to `result`.
372  *
373  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the module is not actually of kind `TIRO_KIND_MODULE`.
374  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_EXPORT_NOT_FOUND` if no exported member with that name exists in this module.
375  *
376  * TODO: Use tiro strings instead of c strings? Or expose symbols?
377  */
378 TIRO_API void tiro_module_get_export(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t module, const char* export_name,
379  tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
380 
381 /** Retrieves the name of this `type` and assigns it to `result`. Returns `TIRO_ERROR_BAD_TYPE` if the value is not a type. */
382 TIRO_API void
383 tiro_type_name(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t type, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
384 
385 /**
386  * Describes a native object type to the tiro runtime. Instances of this type must be provided
387  * to the API when constructing a new native object.
388  *
389  * Native objects that are created with a certain type will continue refencing that type instance by its address.
390  * The lifetime of `tiro_native_type_t` instances is not managued by the runtime, they must remain valid for
391  * as long as there are native objects referring to them.
392  *
393  * \todo DRAFT API. Will probably be replaced with native user defined types.
394  *
395  * \warning The native type instance must not be changed while it is being referenced by native objects!
396  */
397 typedef struct tiro_native_type {
398  /**
399  * The human readable name of this type, mainly for debugging.
400  * Must be a valid zero terminated string.
401  */
402  const char* name;
403 
404  /**
405  * This function will be invoked exactly once for each object when it is being garbage collected.
406  * This member may be NULL if no finalization is needed.
407  *
408  * \param data The address to the native object's data. Any resourced owned by `data` should be freed.
409  * \param size The size of the native object, in bytes.
410  */
411  void (*finalizer)(void* data, size_t size);
412 } tiro_native_type_t;
413 
414 /**
415  * Constructs a new native object of the given type and size.
416  *
417  * `type_descriptor` must describe the properties of the new object. The native object will store a copy of this pointer,
418  * accessible via `tiro_native_type()`. The pointer must remain valid for the lifetime of the object, which
419  * usually means the lifetime of the vm itself.
420  *
421  * `size` (in bytes) specifies the size that will be allocated as user storage and must be greater than 0.
422  *
423  * On success, the constructed object will be written to `result` and the object's user storage will be accessible
424  * via `tiro_native_data()`.
425  */
426 TIRO_API void tiro_make_native(tiro_vm_t vm, const tiro_native_type_t* type_descriptor, size_t size,
427  tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
428 
429 /**
430  * Returns the address of the `tiro_native_type_t` instance that was used to create the given native object.
431  * Returns NULL on error.
432  */
433 TIRO_API const tiro_native_type_t* tiro_native_type_descriptor(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t object);
434 
435 /**
436  * Returns the address of the allocated user storage of the given native object.
437  * Returns NULL on error.
438  */
439 TIRO_API void* tiro_native_data(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t object);
440 
441 /**
442  * Returns the size (in bytes) of the given native object's user storage.
443  * Returns 0 on error.
444  */
445 TIRO_API size_t tiro_native_size(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t object);
446 
447 /**
448  * The prototype of a native function callback that provides a synchronous tiro function.
449  * This type of native function is appropriate for simple, nonblocking operations. Use the more complex asynchronous API
450  * instead if the operation has the potential of blocking the process.
451  *
452  * Note that this API does not allow for custom native userdata. Use native objects instead and pass them in the closure.
453  *
454  * \param vm
455  * The virtual machine the function is executing on.
456  * \param frame
457  * The function call frame. Use `tiro_sync_frame_arg` and `tiro_sync_frame_argc` to access the function
458  * call arguments. Call `tiro_sync_frame_result` to set the return value (it defaults to null if not set).
459  * The closure is also available by calling `tiro_sync_frame_closure`.
460  * The frame value is only valid for the duration of the function call.
461  *
462  * TODO: Exception API
463  */
464 typedef void (*tiro_sync_function_t)(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_sync_frame_t frame);
465 
466 /**
467  * Returns the number of function call arguments present in the given frame.
468  * Returns 0 for invalid input arguments.
469  */
470 TIRO_API size_t tiro_sync_frame_argc(tiro_sync_frame_t frame);
471 
472 /**
473  * Stores the function call argument with the given `index` into `result`.
474  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_OUT_OF_BOUNDS` if the argument index is invalid.
475  */
476 TIRO_API void
477 tiro_sync_frame_arg(tiro_sync_frame_t frame, size_t index, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
478 
479 /** Returns the closure value which was specified when the function was created. */
480 TIRO_API void
481 tiro_sync_frame_closure(tiro_sync_frame_t frame, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
482 
483 /** Sets the return value for the given function call frame to the given `value`. */
484 TIRO_API void
485 tiro_sync_frame_result(tiro_sync_frame_t frame, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_error_t* err);
486 
487 /**
488  * Constructs a new function object with the given name that will invoke the native function `func` when called.
489  * `argc` is the number of arguments required for calling `func`. `closure` may be an arbitrary value
490  * that will be passed to the function on every invocation.
491  *
492  * On success, the new function will be stored in `result`.
493  * Returns `TIRO_BAD_TYPE` if `name` is not a string. Returns `TIRO_BAD_ARG` if the the requested number of parameters
494  * is too large. The current maximum is `1024`.
495  */
496 TIRO_API void tiro_make_sync_function(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t name, tiro_sync_function_t func,
497  size_t argc, tiro_handle_t closure, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
498 
499 /**
500  * The prototype of a native function callback that provides an asynchronous tiro function.
501  * Functions of this type should be used to implement long running operations that would otherwise block
502  * the calling coroutine (for example, a socket read or write).
503  *
504  * Calling an asynchronous function will pause ("yield") the calling coroutine. It will be resumed when
505  * a result is provided to the frame object, e.g. by calling `tiro_async_frame_result`. Attempting to resume
506  * a coroutine multiple times is an error.
507  *
508  * Note that this API does not allow for custom native userdata. Use native objects instead and pass them in the closure.
509  *
510  * \param vm
511  * The virtual machine the function is executing on.
512  * \param frame
513  * The function call frame. Use `tiro_async_frame_arg` and `tiro_async_frame_argc` to access the function
514  * call arguments. Call `tiro_async_frame_result` to set the return value (it defaults to null if not set).
515  * The closure is also available by calling `tiro_async_frame_closure`.
516  *
517  * The frame remains valid until it is freed by the caller by invoking `tiro_async_frame_free` (forgetting to
518  * free a frame results in a memory leak).
519  *
520  * TODO: Exception API
521  */
522 typedef void (*tiro_async_function_t)(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_async_frame_t frame);
523 
524 /**
525  * Frees an async frame. Does nothing if `frame` is NULL.
526  *
527  * Frames are allocated for the caller before invoking the native callback function. They must be freed by calling
528  * this function after async operation has been completed (e.g. after calling `tiro_async_frame_result(...)`).
529  *
530  * \warning *All* async call frames must be freed before the vm itself is freed. If there are pending async operations
531  * when the vm shall be destroyed, always free them first (they do not have to receive a result).
532  */
533 TIRO_API void tiro_async_frame_free(tiro_async_frame_t frame);
534 
535 /** Returns the vm instance that this frame belongs to. Returns NULL on error. */
536 TIRO_API tiro_vm_t tiro_async_frame_vm(tiro_async_frame_t frame);
537 
538 /** Returns the number of function call arguments received by this frame. Returns 0 on error. */
539 TIRO_API size_t tiro_async_frame_argc(tiro_async_frame_t frame);
540 
541 /**
542  * Retrieves the function call argument at the specified index and stores it into `result`.
543  * Returns `TIRO_ERROR_OUT_OF_BOUNDS` if the argument index is invalid.
544  */
545 TIRO_API void tiro_async_frame_arg(
546  tiro_async_frame_t frame, size_t index, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
547 
548 /** Returns the closure value which was specified when the function was created. */
549 TIRO_API void
550 tiro_async_frame_closure(tiro_async_frame_t frame, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
551 
552 /**
553  * Sets the return value for the given function call frame to the given `value`.
554  * Async function frames must be freed (by calling `tiro_async_frame_free`) after they have been completed.
555  */
556 TIRO_API void
557 tiro_async_frame_result(tiro_async_frame_t frame, tiro_handle_t value, tiro_error_t* err);
558 
559 /**
560  * Constructs a new function object with the given name that will invoke the native function `func` when called.
561  * `argc` is the number of arguments required for calling `func`. `closure` may be an arbitrary value
562  * that will be passed to the function on every invocation.
563  *
564  * On success, the new function will be stored in `result`.
565  * Returns `TIRO_BAD_TYPE` if `name` is not a string. Returns `TIRO_BAD_ARG` if the the requested number of parameters
566  * is too large. The current maximum is `1024`.
567  */
568 TIRO_API void tiro_make_async_function(tiro_vm_t vm, tiro_handle_t name, tiro_async_function_t func,
569  size_t argc, tiro_handle_t closure, tiro_handle_t result, tiro_error_t* err);
570 
571 #ifdef __cplusplus
572 } /* extern "C" */
573 #endif
574 
575 #endif // TIRO_OBJECTS_H_INCLUDED
